ratings.question_text: Your level of engagement with the course was:
What is your overall assessment of this course?
The course was well organized to facilitate student learning.
I received clear feedback that improved my learning.
Relative to other courses you have taken at Yale, the level of intellectual challenge of this course was:
Relative to other courses you have taken at Yale, the workload of this course was:

narratives.question_text: What knowledge, skills, and insights did you develop by taking this course?
comments: I grasped a deeper understanding of race, gender, and class. I also learned more about inequity and inequality. By applying the concepts I learned in analyzing American society, I found a lot of things easier to understand.

The racial, gender, and class inequalities and inequities existed in the world, and how is equality different from equity. I also got a new understanding toward the differences between sex and gender. I also foster a correlation between races and classes,  and how these inequalities lead to negative feeling and attitudes, racial segregations, and other affirmatives actions that exaggerate the issue.
Reading materials and express my thoughts in groups and meet people from various countries which enabled for me to deeper widen my thoughts.
Race gender and class, specific terms etc

I learned the facts about and perspectives on the inequity of gender, race, and class in the U.S. I learned that history is important in shaping inequities of a certain society. The most valuable insight is that we must have faith in building a equitable world though it may seem impossible.

-definitions of sociological terms including race, racism, gender, sexism, class, classism
-read current and non current work of sociologists 
-how race, gender, and class have looked in the history of the US and today
-how race, gender, and class are similar, and different, and intersect

i gain more knowledge about inequities, not just in the US, but also from around the world. noticing everyday interaction and how it is actually a real implementation of inequities is such an eye-opening experience
I now understand how the systems work especially in the US!

Learning in this class has enhanced the basic foundation of my understanding regarding race, class, and gender. Through the class readings, lectures, and group discussions, I have further understood race, gender, and class as social constructs and how they affect the daily lives of society. Although the context of the topic in this class mainly caters to the United States, I could implement what I have learned in a broader context of other countries, namely my hometown of Indonesia. Additionally, this class increased my critical thinking, writing, and public speaking skills.

I gained knowledge on the issues of race, gender, and class in the scope of the U.S. and universally. I have learnt that race, gender, and class inequities stem from various issues and affect the micro, macro, and meso levels. I also gained the skills of writing a research proposal and editing academic videos.

narratives.question_text: What are the strengths and weaknesses of this course and how could it be improved?
comments:
The class material is diversified and meaningful, and we together made the classroom a "brave place", where heated discussion constantly took place.
There are a great number of students, so it is hard for the instructor to pay attention to every single person's thoughts and questions. Maybe YSS could set an upper limit on course enrollment and reduce the number of students.

Discussions among huge amount of articles and essays on differnet perspectives and approaches. Very broad range of topics that allow intersections to form between different groups, and also requires great amount of thinking and effort paid into it.
Having discussions with students during class was good to me

Strengths: encourage students to better understand what is happening in the world
Weakness: too many reading materials, limited time

The course has many inspiring materials, including readings and the teacher's PPT. However, it may be difficult for international students without many American cultural backgrounds to understand. It may be improved by explaining some key cultural backgrounds in the readings ahead instead of just bringing them up during discussion.

Strengths
- the Professor was a great lecturer 
- the slideshows 
- the pacing
- the final project

Weaknesses
- some of the readings were too long
i love how the professor trying to gave us example that close with our daily lives. this is the biggest class I've take in YSS, and I think I makes me easily distracted sometimes.
because the people who are in class mostly outside from the US, I only wish there are more US Student so the topics can be more relatable

Strengths:
1. Balanced time allocation for lectures, seminars, and group discussions made it easier to follow the learning process and understand the class materials. 
2. The professor and TAs were proactive and appreciative of every student's responses in class, creating a comfortable environment for students to continue engaging in class discussions. They also provided clear and informative feedback on every assignment, which made it easy for students to keep improving their work.
3. All material resources are organized completely and well on Canvas, making it easier to access.

Weaknesses:
1. The amount of readings differs from how long students have to read everything. Thus, I think it would be helpful if the key terms and PowerPoint presentation slides were given at least 24 hours before class. Therefore, students will have a guide to the readings and a head-start on the most essential terms to focus on.

The strength lies in how interactive the class is -- not only with the lecturers but also between students through group readings and weekly correspondences. The weakness is probably the burden of the pre-readings which can be overwhelming at times but is still tolerable in my opinion.

narratives.question_text: Would you recommend this course to another student? Please explain.
comments: I would. It helps us a lot to learn more about race, gender, and class inequities in the United States. The course readings are informative and interesting. The course debating is also effective for learning.
Can look into race, gender and class inequities in U.S not in perspective of my country.
Yes, its a course that challenged myself in a good way and also have a lot of knowledge

The reason I said "less" to question number 7 is because of my own background knowledge in Sociology. 

I would recommend this class to another student because I learned a lot and loved the format of the class. The class was engaging and had different types of learning and various assignment types. I think any student would benefit and learn from this class, no matter what major.
yes. the professor and the TA's are very helpful and friendly towards the student.

I recommend this course to every student because I find the topic of this class essential for everyone. Understanding the basics of race, class, and gender will help students understand the source and effects of various issues in everyday society, making them passionate about dismantling these issues and becoming agents of change.

Yes. I think the topic of race, gender, and class is a universal topic that can be explored from various points of view. You get to learn in a global setting here with students from all over the world which gives you an even broader insight and knowledge on the issues.

narratives.question_text: How will you use the knowledge and skills you learned in this course in your future endeavors?
comments: This course helps me observe US society from a new angle. In future sociological studies, I definitely will apply what I learned in this course and work out a more fruitful analysis regarding race, gender, and class issues.
Deeper widen my view about the topic

I will pay more attention to what is happening to diverse groups of people around the world and engage in the pursuit of equity. I will also try to apply sociological thinking to counseling to give people more support.
I will use them in my day-to-day life when thinking about social inequity. I will also use them for my future sociology learning and research.
i will tried to applied my knowledge from this class and linked it to my original major as a law student

I will use my knowledge about race, class, and gender and how they operate collectively and individually to create inequities in everyday society. I can implement my understanding of these topics in a broader context, namely societies in other countries while using the United States as a basis. The critical thinking skills I've gained from this class will help me be more aware and passionate about the sources and effects of inequities in daily life.

I will definitely apply the insight I learned in making proposals and videos at my home university which requires me to create a lot of papers and creative media. Furthermore, the materials I learned in this class will also be used in a lot of scopes but mostly academically since I am interested in the issue of gender and film and am planning to pursue that as my concentration in my home university.

extras.title: AFAM S348 01/ER&M S348 01/SOCY S348 01/WGSS S348 01 - Race, Gender, & Class in U.S.
